choices.text: The standard gauge for railways was established in England during the 1830s, when a group of railway companies decided to use a common track width. This decision allowed trains from different lines to interchange seamlessly and encouraged competition among railway operators. The standard gauge quickly became popular throughout Europe and North America, as it provided a consistent size for tracks that could be used by multiple railways without the need for costly modifications or compromises in speed or capacity.
